datafield.subfield: Example code to produce the di-muon spectrum from a CMS 2010 primary dataset
Use this with 2010 Mu primary datasets or any other 2010 primary datasets containing muons (see detailed instructions in code)

This simple analysis example is set up at Research level, i.e. it requires university student level programming experience. Minimal acquaintance with Linux, the Root analysis package https://root.cern.ch/ and a basic text editor.
Use this code with the CMS Open Data VM environment
Only the list of validated runs are accepted:

If you do not have the CMS 2010 Virtual Machine installed follow the instructions in step 1 at How to install a CERN Virtual Machine. Then install and run the Demo (demo analyzer) program following the instructions at How to Test & Validate

To run di-muon spectrum demo:

  • Download the index files for the /Mu/Run2010B-Apr21ReReco-v1/AOD primary data sets and store them in Demo/DemoAnalyzer/datasets/, but first you have to create the directory.
  • Download the JSON file as instructed in CMS Validated Runs and save it to the Demo/DemoAnalyzer/datasets directory.
  • After, replace the three files BuildFile.xml demoanalyzer_cfg.py src/Demoanalyzer.cc by the ones from this record and read the comments in Demoanalyzer.cc if you want to understand what the program does.
  • Then, recompile ("scram b") and rerun ("cmsRun ...") exactly as before How to Test & Validate. You should get an output file Mu.root which contains histograms for 10000 input events (small subset of data). These can be looked at using a Root Browser (see above-Description). The most interesting histogram is GM_mass_log In order to compare with MUO-10-004 it should be viewed with the 'logy' option. Of course with 10000 events the comparison is poor, but the J/psi (at log10(mass)=0.5), Upsilon (at log10(mass=0.98)) and Z (at log10(mass)=1.95, one event only) peaks should be visible.
  • Finally, to run over more or even the full statistics, edit the relevant parts of the Python file demoanalyzer_cfg.py (see comments therein) and rerun. Add up the output histograms from different (nonoverlapping) input index files using Root tools.

]] Dutta, I. Hirvonsalo, H. Sheeran, B. The example output is a ROOT file FIXME: Find the ROOT file in https://cernbox.cern.ch/index.php/s/9Zoq94XAfjg7M7h FIXME: Find the files in https://cernbox.cern.ch/index.php/s/9Zoq94XAfjg7M7h CMS-Tools Research
